binding.p: The manuscript is bound a half binding with blue cloth spine and corners, the boards are covered in brown marbled paper (tree root). Golden lines are dividing the spine into five panels. In the second panel, the gilt tooled title: Varia Exscripta Chronici Grönlandici cum tïtulis manu A. MAGNÄI adscriptis is found. In the bottom panel: A crowned national arms of Denmark supported by two savages with bludgeons. Hanging below, the Order of the Elephant. The binding dates from the time the manuscript was part of the collection of the Royal Library in Copenhagen (which can be inferred from the type of binding and its decoration).

provenance.p: The manuscript was, for some time, a part of the collection of the Royal Library in Copenhagen, catalogued as NkS 1961 4to. In April 1888, the manuscript was returned to the Arnamagnæan Collection.

support.p: Paper with watermark (the coat of arms of Amsterdam).

foliation.p: Modern foliation in pencil. The numbers are not consecutive and have been corrected several times.

collation.catchwords: There are long catchwords on every page.

condition.p: There are lacunae after fols. 2, 4, 10, 24 and possibly more.
The manuscript is in quite poor condition. The paper is very thin and there are many small holes.
Most leaves show older repairs (with paper and Japanese tissue).

list.item: The manuscript is written in one column with 25 to 28 lines per page and 11 to 15 words per line.
On fol. 20v, only 9 lines were written. The text, however, continues on fol. 21r.

handNote.p: This part of the manuscript was written in chancery script by an unidentified scribe.

additions.p: On fol. 20v, there is some writing consisting of two words, perpendicular to the direction of the text. This could be a name or signature.

accMat.p: An AM-slip ( 183 143 ) in Árni Magnússon's hand is found at the beginning of the manuscript: Fra Monsieur Þorleifi Arasyne til läns 1711. i Augusto.
A later hand has addded No 1 in pencil.

acquisition.p: Árni Magnússon received this part from Þorleifur Arason in August 1711.

support.p: Paper with two different watermarks (the coat of arms of Amsterdam and a foolscap).

condition.p: The paper is thin and has many small holes.
There are older repairs and many stains.

list.item: The manuscript is written in one column with 35 to 42 lines per page and 13 to 18 words per line.

handNote.p: Written in a hybrid script which has been identified as Steindór Ormsson's hand.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are decorated initials of varying size (1-9) at the beginning of the chapters.

On fol. 24v a large decorated initial ("I") marking the beginning of a new text is found. Unlike the text, the initial is not crossed-out. Its size corresponds to 9 lines of text. An almost identical initial is found at the same location in AM 779 c III 4to (30v).

accMat.p: An AM-slip ( 194 147 ) in Árni Magnússon's hand is pasted to the first page of the manuscript. It says: Grænlands=chronica utlögd af Jone Olafssyne Ost=india=fara. Below, another hand added: Ur bök i 4to sem Eg keypte 1710. af Jörunne i ytra Hiardardal i Önundar firde, konu Jons Steindorssonar yngra. Er med hende Steindors Ormssonar. A.M.
A later hand has added No 2 in pencil.

acquisition.p: Árni Magnússon bought the manuscript from Jórunn, Jón Steindórsson's widow, in 1710.

physDesc.accMat:

history.origin: The manuscript was formerly part of a larger codex, including i.e. AM 540 4to, AM 347 4to V and AM 554 a γ 4to.

acquisition.p: It is unknown when Árni Magnússon acquired the manuscript, but he received it from Staður in Sugandafjörður (see the second AM-slip).

msItem.note: Translation. The same as in AM 779 a 4to-AM 779 b 4to and AM 779 c V 4to.

support.p: Paper with a large ornamented watermark.

collation.catchwords: There are catchwords on every page.

condition.p: There are older repairs and many stains.

list.item: The manuscript is written in one column with 27 to 31 lines per page and 14 to 17 words per line.

handDesc.handNote: Written in a kurrent script by Halldór Guðmundsson á Sílastöðum.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are decorated initials of varying size (1-3 lines) at the beginning of the chapters.
Parts of the rubrics are written in red ink.
There is a small tail-piece at the end of the text.

additions.p: At least one later hand added underlinings to the text and markers in the outer margins.

accMat.p: An AM-slip ( 195 160 ) in Árni Magnússon's hand is found at the beginning of the manuscript: Ur bok Sera Þorsteinskels Oddz sonar i Bæ, og heyrer honum til, ä eg og at lata þad festa til samans aptur.
A later hand has added No 5 in pencil.
accMat.note: This slip belongs to AM 779 c V 4to, as indicated at the bottom of the slip: Á við V aftast í bókina.

provenance.p: Árni Magnússon received the manuscript as part of a larger codex from Jón Torfason. Initially, this was a loan, but in 1721 he became the owner of the manuscript (cf. the AM-slip belonging to AM 779 c V 4to).

collation.catchwords: There are catchwords on every page.

list.item: The manuscript is written in one column with 24 to 28 lines per page and 13 to 15 words per line.

handDesc.handNote: Written in kurrent script by an unidentified scribe.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are larger decorated chapter initials (3-5).
At the end of the text, there are three small tail-pieces.

additions.p: There are some additions in the margins and on fol. 26v in brown ink. The ink is smeared, so the additions are now illegible.

accMat.p:
An AM-slip ( 190 153 ) in Árni Magnússon's hand, kept with the manuscript, reads: Grænlandz-Kronika
Ur bok Sera Jons Torfasonar ä Breidabolstad, og heyrir honum til nu 1721 hun mier til.
A later hand wrote No 7 in pencil onto the AM-slip.
Another hand wrote 5 in black ink onto the AM-slip.
accMat.note: This slip belongs to the last item, i.e. part IV, as is indicated in a note at the bottom of the slip: Á við IV hér framan.

provenance.p: Árni Magnússon borrowed the manuscript as part of a larger codex from Þorkell Oddsson in Gaulverjabær (cf. the AM-slip of AM 779 c IV 4to).
